These two lines in the song represent the exact moment when the parents realized their error in raising their daughter.  The parallelism in “What did we do that was wrong” and “We didn’t know it was wrong” reflects how they took one train of thought, and allowed it to turn the opposite direction (a contrast within parallelism).

She (We gave her most of our lives)

The lyrics in brackets are from the point of view of the parents, who believe that she is betraying them  by leaving. They believe that it is unjust for her to leave after the amount of time and effort they put in trying to raise her.

However, this may simply be proving her apparant view that the environment that they provide her with was worthy of evading, as the parents seem to have adopted a selfish approach to the situation – it’s about what they “sacrificed” for her, not about their love for her.

This poetic liberty McCartney takes in the retelling of the story provided a lot of speculation and confusion about who Melanie’s boyfriend was at the time. Many people had suspected it was Terry Doran, a friend of theirs who worked in a car showroom. But McCartney cleared that up in an interview:

It was just fiction, like the sea captain in Yellow Submarine; they weren’t real people. The man from the motor trade was just a typical sleazy characer, the kind of guy that could pull a young bird by saying, ‘Would you like a ride in my car, darlin’?’ Nice plush interior, that’s how you pulled birds. So it was just a nice little bit of sleaze.

[Verse 1: Paul McCartney]

These lyrics were based on a newspaper that story Paul McCartney had read about a runaway girl. On February 27th, 1967 the London Daily Mail’s headline read:

A-level girl dumps car and vanishes."

The girl that ran away was 17-year-old Melanie Coe who describes a poignantly tragic tale in an interview with The Guardian. Her father was quoted as saying,

I cannot imagine why she should run away, she has everything here."

McCartney said in 1000 UK #1 Hits by Jon Kutner and Spencer Leigh,

We’d seen that story and it was my inspiration. There was a lot of these at the time and that was enough to give us the storyline. So I started to get the lyrics: she slips out and leaves a note and the parents wake up, it was rather poignant. I like it as a song and when I showed it to John, he added the Greek chorus and long sustained notes. One of the nice things about the structure of the song is that it stays on those chords endlessly."

The line stating “she is free”, suggests that she thought of her parents home as a bubble that imprisoned her and kept her from the outside world.
